iv
1
CHAPTER 1
The gate- crasher
It was a humid sweltering day. The sky was slightly blanketed by
scattered clouds. About ten kilometres ahead off her she could see the
Drakensburg Mountain. From her distance the green grass and lush
vegetation covering the Mountain made it looked like a dark blue blanket
belting the horizon.
She was glad that it was all over and she was on her way home. She
didn’t have to board a taxi since it was about thirty minutes’ walk from
the shopping complex to her place. Cars of assorted colours were
buzzing past on the R40 main road as she walked along the sidewalk.
She was dog tired as she dragged her legs.
She continued to walk wearily until she reached the T-junction. She
stood under the shade of the jackal-berry tree which was opposite the
main road. She exhaled exasperatingly and continued walking. She
plodded on until she reached section ten off-ramp and branched away
from the main road, turned to the left and walked along the paving
flanking the street cutting through rows of houses. The sweat in her eyes
became moist and itchy. She wiped them with a handkerchief.
What a pig of a day; she thought. She didn’t have to endure the
steaming weather only, but also a long queue at the automated teller
machine (ATM). She felt as if her legs were logs punching in her hips as
she trudged along. Her back which was blanketed by a sweating baby
felt moist and itchy as if a swarm of bees were crawling on it.
2
Her heart glowed with hope at the sight of a cream four roomed
house. She saw a dove flying past. It flapped its wings in pride as if
mocking at her snail-pace progress. Within few minutes it was flying past
her four roomed house. She envied the ethereal creature. If I could fly I
would be at home by now, she thought.
Instinctively, she was overwhelmed with nostalgia. She found herself
humming a praising song:
‘We praise the Lord
Alleluia!
Alleluia!
Alleluia!
We praise Lord! An excerpt from a distant past flashed in her mind. She
saw herself amidst church members singing and praising vibrantly. That
was then; before she met Takala. Takala! She shook her head in
dismay.
Her mind flashed back. She realised that she was then few paces away
from the gate. She walked on wearily until she reached the gate, stopped
and exhaled with relief before opening it and entered. She walked along
the expanse of the compound to the house. She stopped at the door,
took out a key from her handbag, unlocked, opened the door, entered
and closed the door behind her. She ignored the sofas and made a bee-
line to the main bedroom. She unlocked the door and entered. She stood
next to the queen size bed, removed the baby from her back and laid
him on the bed. A whiff of fresh air whipped her back. She felt a tingling
sensation as unrestrained trickle of sweat started to roll down her spine.
3
She removed her blouse and wiped herself with a towel. She also
mopped cluster of sweat beads on the forehead of the baby. She then
went to the bathroom and had a long warm bath. The baby was still
asleep when she finished. She got dressed and preened herself in front
of the mirror.
Thereafter she sat on the bed with her arms crossed on her lap. She
took out R100.00 notes from her purse and counted them. After
counting she held the money with her hand, wafted it back and forth
while masked with an expression of disinterest and doubts on her face.
She exhaled and squealed with despair. Events of the past few days
unfurled in her mind. “I deposited the money into your account,” he had
said during their telephone conversation.
“Oh! Thank you darling, she had replied.’’
‘’We need to meet and talk.’’
“Talk about what?”
“I will tell you when we meet”.
“I will come over to your place then.”
“Why don’t we meet at Rivoni Lounge?”
“Why do we have to meet at the lounge? We can also meet at your
place”.
“Since the death of your sister my mom and siblings are always in the
house. I don’t want any eavesdropping to our conversation.”
“You’re scaring me Takala. I wonder what kind of a business is there
between us to warrant such privacy; or are we going to plan a coup?’’
‘’I wouldn’t choose a bundle of nerves like you for that task.’’
4
‘’Then what is it.’’
‘’Letta! Asking to meet you at the lounge is it too much to ask?’’
‘’I can’t help it Takala; not with so many stories of people disappearing
without a trace,’ she jested.
‘’Do I look like a serial killer to you?’’
‘’Serial killers are not labelled. They charm their victims.’’
‘’You don’t stop to amuse me you know,’’ he said with a chuckle.
‘’You know as much as I know that what I am saying is not a myth. I’m
sure you’re reading about this in Daily sun every day.’’
‘’Do we have to go that far? I mean do you mistrust me to that extend?’’
‘’May be you should drop a hint in order to stop this cat and a mouse
game. That will serve us our precious time; most especially your air
time.’’
‘’I prefer to tell you everything when we meet.’’
‘’And that has to be at the lounge?’’
‘’That is right.’’
‘’What will people say because you’re still mourning for my sister? Don’t
you think it is immoral and unethical to sneak around at the lounge with
your sister in law? To make matters worse I am married. What do you
think will happen if Topson can find out that I’m meeting you at the
lounge?’’
“Please Letta! I am begging you! We can meet at mid-day when it is
quiet.”
“What is there to discuss anyway?”
“We need to discuss the future of our baby.”
5
“We discussed that long ago.”
“Yes, but it was before your sister died.”
“No Takala! I respect you as my brother in law but you are now
overstepping your territory.”
“You forget something; I’m not only your brother in law but also the father
of your baby”.
What he didn’t know was that she had never forgiven herself for their
romantic escapade for which she paid dearly. As a result those words
tore into her heart like a sharp sword. She felt as if he was exposing and
scarifying her pus infested sore which was festering in her heart
throughout her married life.” What have you just said? I don’t believe
this. Have you forgotten what you said when I told you that I was having
a bun in the oven? I had to deceive Topson into believing that the baby
was his. As a result I now feel like a lying whore to my husband because
of you.”
“Maybe it was our destiny.”
‘’Do you call cheating on my sister by impregnating her naïve little sister
a destiny? How can you…?” She couldn’t finish the sentence but
snapped the stop button of her mobile and burst out into tears. He had
called her again but she did not answer. He sent her an SMS which
read:’’ I’m deeply sorry Letta; I didn’t mean to hurt you, help me please!
My heart is breaking.” An excerpt of her sister’s coffin being lowered into
the grave whilst he cried convulsively flashed into her mind. She felt a
twinge of sympathy and called him.
6
“Thank you Letta! I’m terribly sorry. If you don’t want to meet me its fine,
but forgive me,” he said on the other end of the line.
“All right’, she said and discontinued the call again.
Her train of thoughts was disturbed by a rap. She stiffened and listened
carefully. It was from the lounge. She stood up and quickly took a stool
beneath the dressing table; placed it next to the wardrobes and climbed
on it. She then opened the closet and pushed the money between the
folds of the duvet. She shut the closet, jumped down and rushed to the
lounge while the rap continued furiously. She stopped next to the door.
“Who is that?” She asked.
“It’s Mr Potter,” bellowed the voice outside. She hesitantly reached for
the door latch with a fleck of fear and slowly opened. A burly man
hurtled inside. She stepped out of his way to avoid being knocked over.
“Good afternoon sir”, she said while dropping a curtsey to him with fear.
He didn’t respond but just stood and cursorily swept the room with his
big eyes which stuck out like those of an owl. It was as if she did not
exist. After a long moment he directed an ominous glare towards her.
He looked at her for a long moment. As if he was waking up from a
dream, he started to recognise her. Events which happened at Super
Spar flashed back to his mind.’’ Hey! You’re so beautiful my girl. My
heart nearly stopped beating when I saw you,’’ he had said to her. She
had looked at him wide-eyed with amazement and horror. ‘’Are you not
shy to talk to your daughter like that.
I mean you’re old as my father,’’ she had said loudly. He winced at her
nonsensical impolite response. To add salt to the wound the shop was
7
full. He knew at once that any further dialogue with her would attract
attention. He had sped off passed her without looking back. And now,
here she is. So tantalising as he saw her at the shop. Her round breasts
were so enticing like the Garden of Eden. Her horror-stricken face made
her more beautiful than he saw her at the shop. He looked at her for a
long moment. So you’re the bitch who took the micky out of me at Spar.’’
He clapped his hands while cackling.’’ Felicitation! She looked at him in
horror. Her heart thumped faster. She wished it was just a dream or it
was simply a pigment of her imagination. His egg-shaped stomach
above his thin waist made her think of a tad-pole jumping into the pool.
His bloodshot eyes which stuck out from his frog-like face were
glowering at her. Oh alas! Let the devil rot in hell, she cursed. While
shaking with fear. Had he traced her? What will he do to me? This is a
damn small world, she reflected with a knot in her stomach. She didn’t
answer but only wrung her hands with fear like a trapped rat. She
couldn’t take her eyes off him lest he would step closer to her.
His eyes moved from her feet to her head. So for a change this good for
nothing wimp is having something I cannot have unless I risk going to
jail. Who does he think he is? God forbid if this weakling get away with
this! He fumed. When she stole another glance at him he was still glaring
at her. It was as if he would devour her with his eyes. She hesitated
and didn’t know what to do. She wanted to cry; yelp; run whilst shivering.
In her heart the silence which ensued was palpable. It was as if the roof
would fall on her. All her emotions were stifled as if she was
electrocuted.
8
‘’ Where is Topson? ’’He asked while scowling at her.
“He is at work.”
“Listen carefully, when he comes back tell him Mr Potter was here. Also
tell him to stop playing games with me. Do you hear?”
“Yes”, she replied.
He went out of the house leaving the door ajar without saying another
word. She rushed to the john immediately he stepped out of the house.
Her eyes were red and trickling. When she came back she closed the
door and sat on the sofa. She tried to figure out what kind of a nasty
business was brewing between her husband and this monster. Is this a
tip of an iceberg of many secrets he is hiding from me, she wondered.
She was still engrossed in her thoughts when she heard his familiar
footsteps approaching.
“Knock! Knock! Is somebody home?” He called.
He opened the door without waiting for a respond. She only looked at
him icily. “Why”? He asked. He knew instantly that something was
wrong somewhere. That was not a welcome he was accustomed to; like
honey! Sweetheart! Hi husband, etc. ‘’It seems I deserve a spank today’’,
he jested. He was deliberately challenging her warmth which he was
starting to miss with a fleck of fear. There she was, deadly quiet like a
figurine. He looked at her with alarm. ’Is anything wrong.’’
After a long moment she stood up; still looking at him. It seems there
are lot of wrongs in this family,’’ she said while turning against him and
proceeded to the main bedroom. He followed her. They sat on the bed
and looked at each other. There was an ominous silence between them.
9
For the first time they felt like strangers.’’ Topson! What is your business
with Mr Potter?”
Her words hit him like a bomb. His heartbeat drummed louder. He
realized instantly that from that moment his day was not going to be a
picnic. A can of worms he had hoped would remain closed was now
open, stinking as it had never been. Events which gave birth to his
predicament flashed back to his mind.
It was December 15 during their pay day, he remembered. Their Office
had decided to celebrate their end of the year party at Nkwangulatilo
hotel. It was a flashy hotel with all kinds of games like casino, lottery, etc.
His colleagues were gambling while he sauntered around watching
them. ‘’ Mr Makhandla why don’t you try your luck? Who knows that you
might go home being a millionaire’’, Mr Xipanga one of his co-worker had
said.
“I might as well go home broke”
“No man! Stop jittering and try your luck.” He had however decided to try
his luck and played with R10 only. He had won R200 instantly. His
stroke of luck encouraged him. The possibility of winning more money
had started to affirm itself. He kept on playing hoping that his stroke of
luck would be repeated.
He was unconsciously bitten by the buck. By the time they were set to
go he had already used half of his salary; severely depleting the family
budget. How will I explain all this to Leta?He had freaked. Throughout
their journey back home he was miserable. He had however concealed
his hilarious fiasco to his colleagues. To avoid humiliating confrontation
10
with Letta he had borrowed some money from the loan shark. Because
of hefty interest of his loan he had to borrow extra money after paying off
his loan in order to survive. Mr Porter would give him the money with a
broad smile while he winced with shame. How long will I continue to be
his milk cow? He had wondered. He was thinking about applying for a
loan at the bank in order to pay him off; hence his delay in going to him.
Now the filthy swine has revealed everything to his wife. Where do I start
explaining all this? He wondered.
Topson! Please stop stalling and explain. After your cannibal frightened
the life out of me you owe me the whole truth’’.
He sighed. “Darling I’m so sorry!’’
‘’Spare me your apology and tell me what is going on.’’
‘’Mr Potter is a loan shark.’’
‘’What? A mashonisa?’’
‘’Yes!’’
‘’Are you saying we are eating from the hands of loan sharks in this
house? Do you know how rude those moles can be sometimes? How
can you-?’’ She stopped and burst into tears.
Topson just sat there-flustered like a snared hare. He had never seen
her that angry. She was breathing fire and brimstone. A feeling of regret
overwhelmed him. He reckoned that lying could be rubbing salt into the
wound. He fervently spilled out the whole truth. His eyes were glistening
with tears when he finished his story. I am terribly sorry. The fact that I
made a stupid mistake does not change the fact that I love you deeply.
11
You and Jabulile are the best thing in my life. The tumultuous world is
dead in my heart except you. Sometimes I feel like winging you to a
planet where there are no worries and pains. Maybe that is why I made
that stupid mistake. He stopped and looked at her miserably. The fact
that he also loved Jabulile; in fact Takala’s son was a thorn in her heart.
It was He who named the baby Jabulile which means happy. He had
told her that he was very happy for the wonderful gift she has brought to
the Makhandla’s family.
She couldn’t avoid tears from flowing down her face when she heard
those words. Throughout their married life she had never doubted his
commitment to her and the baby. One day he had said:’’ I want you to
know this; real beauty is the loving heart. There’s no happiness in
beauty which is only skin deep. Amongst all my weaknesses don’t miss
the beauty of the love oozing out of my heart for you.’’ She started
regretting for being hard on him as she remembered this. All I’m giving
him is a paternal lie. Moreover I am throwing tantrums at him for making
a small mistake. A feeling of guilt and compassion gripped her.’’ I’m also
sorry for being emotional and judgemental before hearing you out. I was
only freaked out.’’
‘’That means you forgive me.’’
In reply she smiled mischievously and said:’’ I guess you know that
nothing for mahala-nothing for free.’’
‘’Name your price then.’’
‘’Come,’’ ‘she said with a smile while waving both hands at him. With
relieve he surrendered himself into her embrace. The soft brush of her
12
breast was more comforting. She then released him and took both his
hands into hers. Slowly and dramatically she craned forward to kiss him.
He also came closer; his mouth ready for the lovely offer. She stopped
half way; put her forefinger across his mouth while smiling fetchingly.
’You’re so wonderful my Husband.’’
‘’And you? You’re so masturbating!”
‘’Wow! Let’s see if you are correct. She tenderly kissed him while
placing her hand on his neck and running her fingers around his ears.
Her other hand was caressing his thigh and explored further. When he
started to whine with excitement she released him while laughing
heartily. ‘’ Forgiven,’’ she said. ‘’ Tell me; how much do we owe that
eagle; that carnivore.’’
‘’Three thousand rends.’’
‘’My Uncle sent me some money,’’ she lied. I will give you the money to
get this bugger off our backs.’’
She suddenly became sprightly as if she had been injected with new
energy. She looked at him. Hey, you didn’t see him when he shot into
the house like a missile. He would have knocked me over if I had not
stepped out of his way. He was like an angry wolf. Thanks God he
didn’t eat me alive.’’
‘’Sorry for all this! I will pay you two fold for your price.’’ He said while
throwing himself into her arms again. However, his heart was in his
boots. He was still thinking about his ordeal long after Letta had started
snoring. It seems my problems have become a series. Oh! Help me God!
He prayed tearfully.
13
CHAPTER 2
Lindsy cooper
He reached the gate of the magistrate office; stopped, looked at the
white walled and black tiles roofed building. On both sides of the drive-
way was an immaculately manicured lawn interspersed with beautiful
flowers. He slowly entered the gate and waved at the security guards as
he passed. They smiled back at him. He proceeded along the drive-way
towards the building. After walking few paces he stood and looked at the
building for along moment. A profound feeling of wistful nostalgia tinted
with a weird sense of belonging gripped him.
His mother died while he was still young. He had asked his grandmother
on several occasions about his father before she died. She told him that
she also didn’t know him since his mother refused to tell her. ‘’She died
with that secret sealed in her heart my son,’’ she had said. Makhandla
was his mother maiden surname. Thus, he didn’t know where to start
tracing his legitimate clan. Therefore people in that building were his
extended family members. As the bible say: ‘’In the large house there
are articles not only of gold and silver, but also of wood and clay; some
are for noble purpose and some for ignoble.’’ The same applies to
people working in this building, he thought. Some are bitch-hearted like
Cain’s. Others are having hearts of gold. He knew all of them inside out.
Experience had taught him that lips and tongues can lie with impunity;
but not the eyes. The eyes will always expose the hypocrite in you like
an open book. Their twinkling, squint, sarcastic and compassionate
glances tell more than you’re willing to reveal.
14
As his legs leisurely carried him forward he was being gnawed by a
feeling of guilt. His mind was occupied and he couldn’t remember why.
He cudgelled his brain in search for the cause of his discomfort. Like a
deluge hurtling forward it flushed back to his mind. It is my show-down
with Letta yesterday, he remembered with a ray of fear. Although she
appeared to have forgiven me but I am not sure if her pardon has a sting
in the tail. Will she ever trust me again, he wondered. ‘’Are you saying
we are eating from the hands of loan sharks in this house? Do you know
how rude those moles can be sometimes?’’ The shock and anger which
was written all over her face when she said those words could hardly be
erased easily.
His mind was still in the clouds when a car glided to a stop behind him.
The driver looked at him as he dreamily walked in the middle of the road.
He’s day-dreaming as usual, she thought. She placed her hand on the
steering to sound a horn but hesitated. That will freak him out. She
slightly revved up the engine. He looked back abruptly and sprinted off
the road like a horror-stricken child. Damn! I am a bitch, she thought with
a wave of guilt. She rolled down the window with a concerned frown and
looked at him as he stood at the edge of the road; ashen faced. ‘’Sorry
Topson dear! I didn’t mean to------‘’.
He saw her wretched face and a pang of regret slashed his heart. He
cut her mid-sentence and said: ‘’No! No! Don’t do that to yourself Tecy.
This is not your fault. In fact it’s me who should be apologising to you.’’
She looked at him solicitously. She felt sorry and awed at the same
time for his honesty despite this harassment.
15
‘’Oh shame! Come closer dear.’
He went closer and stooped by the front window.’’ I am really sorry
Tecy.’’
‘’You know what Topson?’’
‘’I don’t know.’’
‘’You are a man of honour.’’
‘’Do you call me a man of honour for sleep-walking on the street?’’
‘’I wouldn’t put it like that.’’
‘Then how would you put it?’’
‘’I would say you were fantasizing. Moreover it can be rewarding if all
your fantasy can instruct a pen to dance on a paper.’’
He looked at her with amazement. What a brilliant hypothesis, he
thought. He was thinking about those words long after their impetuous
encounter. ‘Thanks Tecy! You are a woman of honour yourself.’’
It is me who should be thanking you Topson. I am glad that it happened
to be you. Someone would skin me alive for scaring the daylight out of
him.’
‘’The same applies to me or rather it would be worse in my case. You
know that they always enjoy taking the micky out of me. Someone would
subject me to a public pillory.’’
She knew better not to deny what he was saying.
What Topson didn’t know was that his colleagues liked his company
because he was humble and indiscriminately treat them with respect.
The problem was that he unconsciously shied them away because of his
quiet and reserved personality. Any wise person will tell you that rejected
16
love can turn to hate sometimes. Tecy knew all that. She looked at him
sympathetically. ‘’Let us forget about this incident. Tell me how you are
doing my friend.’’
‘’I am all right and you?’’
‘’I am also all right. Just remember to be careful next time.’’
‘’All right Tecy.’’
She waved at him and proceeded towards the parking lots. Topson went
towards the entrance of the building.
He reached the porch; entered the corridor and proceeded along the
passage to Mr Raduma’s office. He reached the office, opened the door
and stepped in. A middle aged woman was mopping the table as he
entered. Her heart glowed when she saw him. All the cleaners liked him.
’’ Good morning Topson.’’
‘Morning mom’, he replied as he bent to sign the attendance register.
After signing he went to his office. He knew that there would be clients
waiting for him. They always came early in order to be first in the queue.
He reached his office and fleetingly surveyed his clients who were
anxiously waiting for him. Amongst them he saw an Indian lady who
looked at him with penetrating gaze which seemed to pierce through to
his mind. He secretly glanced at her unflinching steady eyes. When their
eyes met he flicked away bashfully. Even after avoiding her eyes he
became conscious of her gaze directed at him. He felt as if she was
prying into the privacy of his heart and squinted with irritation.
17
If I was the governor I would outlaw what she is doing, he thought. As if
sensing his discomfort, she shifted her eyes to her handbag, rummaged
through it, took out a small diary and leafed through the pages, frowning.
‘Yes madam. May I help you?’
‘No, no! Please proceed with other clients and I’ll be the last. He served
his clients silently. His mind flashed back to her immediately his last
client stepped out of the office. She stood up and went to the counter.
She was 5.5 feet tall. Her eye-lashes above her toned face were slightly
adorned with mascara, and she had a silky and flawless skin. Her
relaxed hair was done in wave-like curls and on the sides parallel to her
ears they were stretched downwards like dangling black laps. She wore
golden earrings and glittering necklaces hung loosely around her neck.
She was wearing a long black skirt structured to reveal her sinuous
figure and a white blouse. Around her waist was a thick belt decorated
with golden rings woven in a zigzag pattern. The blouse overlapped her
waist concealing the waistband of her skirt.
Sweet smell of her perfume preceded her. She wore a charming smile
as she approached the counter and stood in front of him. She was so
business-like from her appearance. He was instinctively consumed with
admiration for her and wondered what kind of assistance she needed
from him. His was a maintenance office and his clients were usually
collecting money for maintenance from their spouses or ex-spouses who
had been ordered by the court. Most of them were peasants from the
rural areas. He stole a glance at her. No she doesn’t fall under that
category, he reckoned.
18
She looked at him. There was a melancholy expression in him. She
saw in him everything Mr Potter said about him. I don’t want to lose him
Mary. He’s one of my valued clients; he will jump at every single
opportunity to make extra cash, he added.
”Good morning,” she greeted him.
“Good morning Madam.”
“I’m Lindsy Cooper.”
“I’m Topson Makhandla, How may I help?”
“I’m looking for a certain guy by the name of Witness Ngubane who was
working for the Department of Health.”
“I’m sorry madam; I don’t know any one bearing that man. This is the
Magistrate office.”
“Yes I know, but I came here hoping that someone who’s working with lot
of people might help me to trace him. In fact he is my business partner.”
“What kind of business?”
“Well, what I can disclose at the moment is that it’s not a difficult job but
we are making lot of money.” She squint her eyes and slightly shook her
head in despair.
“What’s wrong madam?”
“I’m worried because there’s a business deal we must negotiate on
Thursday. I’m afraid because if I don’t find this guy we will lose lot of
money.”
“I’m sorry I can’t help you.”
She exhaled dejectedly, looked at him pleadingly with her right palm
cupping her chin.
19
“Do you know someone who’s looking for a part time job?”
“What kind of people are you looking for?”
“Are you interested?”
“You’ll have to tell me the details of the job before I answer that.”
“Then it means we need to talk when you knock off duty.”
“Do you want us to meet today? Can’t we fix an appointment for
tomorrow?” He knew that as much as it was important to meet this lady it
was also important to inform Letta not to expect him at a usual time.
Unfortunately they both didn’t have mobile phones.
“I am sorry it can’t be postponed because time is against us since I said
that there is a business deal which must be negotiated on Thursday. It
means if you decide to join us I must introduce you to my business
partners tomorrow.”
Part of him wanted to reject her offer but he was eager to know about the
lucrative deal she was talking about. It can be a solution to my financial
freedom. Letta will have to forgive me because I can’t miss this
opportunity, he thought.
“Alright then,” he replied with a nod.
“What time do you knock off?”
“At 4.30pm.”
“I will go and attend to my other business and at 4.30 pm I will be at the
parking. I will be waiting for you in a silver grey BMW.’’
“All right then.”
Xxxxxxxxxxxx
20
They were going to Calabary Lounge and were cruising at sixty
kilometres per hour. The venue was Lindsy’s suggestion. She had said

CHAPTER 3
Mis-match
Zelda Phiri was sitting on the queen size bed which was covered with a
fawn duvet that matched a fluffy carpet. The sumptuous fawn curtain
was draped over the window on the eastern side of the room. On the left
side of the room was a vase of dracaena. The room was spick and span.
She was twenty four years old; five point 1.4 metres tall, silky skin,
immaculately curled hair and blue eyes. She wore a silver grey bathrobe

She remembered with a pang of guilt that she forgot clothes from the

Since she started staying in that house she had never stopped admiring

giving it a yellowish colour. The pitch-black main road streaking past
rows of dominantly four roomed houses seemed like a black lining to the
beautiful golden surface. She wished she could stay there and indulge

went inside the house and sat on the bed again.
Memories unfurled in her mind as she stared at the picture. She was
from a family of five. It was herself, their parents, her elder brother Raska
who was the first born in the family and her elder sister Webile.
They were staying at Rakhuma village which was ten kilometres on
the Southern side of Marubi village. The two villages were bordered by
28
Sereshe River. Rakhuma village stretched from the river up to the far
southern side of Juju Mountain. Beyond the mountain was another
village called Phakata. Legend had it that on the mountain there was a
very big snake which emitted a light at night. Its head resembled that of a
woman while its bottom was a snake. That’s balderdash; she thought
contemptuously. Anyway, who had ever seen that snake, she wondered
dismissively.
The economic status of the villagers used to be measured by the type
of houses they built. The poor would only afford to build thatch roofed
mud huts. The middle class would build flat houses and the rich tiled
roofed houses.
The poor villagers earned their living from farming. The middle class
were headed by proletariat men. Many of them were working at the
mines around Gauteng which was seven hundred kilometres away. The
rich were teachers, nurses, business men owning retail shops and
vendors going around touting for customers.
Zelda’s family was within the enclave of the middle class. Their father
was working at a coal mine at Witbank. They were not living a lavish life
but their father was able to provide for their basic needs; that is food and
clothing. They would see their father quarterly. He would come home for
a weekend - off after three months and for Christmas holidays in
December. Like other housewives, their mother used to spend most of
her time farming at the northern outskirt of the village next to the river.
The staple food in their family was soft porridge for breakfast, porridge
and vegetables for lunch and supper. The only time they would taste

Her aunt survived by babysitting jobs. She was not married and had
no children of her own. She cohabited with three different men in her life.

Her aunt resumed full parental responsibility to her after she had been

Mr Caserula looked at the man who was entering his office. He was six

He avoided being supercilious and by so doing he was able to win the
confidence of his patients.

disturbance of the mind or emotions caused by bad news or a frightening
event. It is important that one gets over it because it leads to depression.
120
Depression can aggravate to a post-traumatic disorder. This is the

CHAPTER 10
Good riddance
It was Friday noon and the sky was crystal clear. Shimmering waves of
the sun’s rays could be seen at the distance.
Zelda was standing at the door of the lounge facing the tarred main

overhead.

She was overwhelmed by a profound sense of ennui.

heart throbbed faster. She knew the sensation portend a bad omen.
Something bad will happen to me, she thought helplessly.

“Our father:

Alleluya Amen”.
The soprano was resonating like a sparrow, an alto cooing like a dove,

which were streaming down her cheeks.

Epilogue
Topson was sitting in the lounge. Tears were rolling down his cheeks
while holding a letter in his hand. Zelda emerged from the bedroom and
came to sit next to him. She nearly jumped out of her skin when she saw
his tears. She stood next to him enthralled with horror. What the hell is
happening now?” She exclaimed with a deep feeling of sympathy. She
thought about what he had gone through. She wondered what might
have cropped up now.
“Why are you crying?” She asked sympathetically.
He languidly handed her the letter. She accepted it, shaking with
trepidation. She went through it. It read as follows:
Topson:
I won’t blame you if you hate me to death for what I’ve done and for what
I’m about to tell you. I’m sorry to be doing this. There’ll never be a polite
way of spilling the beans about my dirty and selfish secret. However hard
I try to be polite, my stinking secret will always be blunt as it could ever
be. That’s why I don’t have a choice but to let the cat out of the bag:
Jabulile is not your son Topson. I know this is Greek to you. But that’s
the way the cookie crumbles. Jabulile is my brother in law’s son. I was
already pregnant when we met.
Then, why am I spilling the beans? My sister died in a car crash. Her
husband (Jabulile’s father) is widowed. That’s why we have decided to
get married. In light of my revelation above, it is in the best interests for
both of us to forget that we ever met.
204
I’m sorry Topson; but there’s no use in crying over spilt milk. I repeat;
I’m sorry! If you call me a witless egocentric bitch I will understand you
Topson. I’m the worst devil.
Bye!
Have a good start
Letta
Zelda finished reading the letter. “Dammit! That arch-bitch,” She said
disgustedly. “I’m sorry Topson. That girl was the devil incarnate. Maybe
this is the right time to tell him the good news, she thought, “Topson! I
think it will dry your tears to know that I’m pregnant.”
‘You what?” asked Topson.
“Pregnant,” she averred with a smile.
“Yip-pee!” He yelled as he jumped up and down clapping his hands.
“Thank you sweetheart-that’s great!”
He hugged and kissed her passionately.
‘’No bastard will come between us.’’
“I’m glad it’s you who’s saying this. I’m also happy that we will bury our
past and start with a clean slate.”
“Exactly that’s correct.’’
“You know what?”
Zelda looked at her husband passionately. “I’m glad we are married.
But with the two, I mean Pat and Letta; they will go and marry in hell.”
Simultaneously, they laughed their lungs out in each other’s arms.
